definition: conspiracy theory
overcast (weather)/cloudy/shady/Yin (the negative principle of Yin and Yang)/negative (electric.)/feminine/moon/implicit/hidden/genitalia
surname Yin
to plan/to seek/scheme
abbr. for 論語|论语[Lun2 yu3], The Analects (of Confucius)
opinion/view/theory/doctrine/to discuss/to talk about/to regard/to consider/per/by the (kilometer, hour etc)

sentences.english: Conspiracy theories always leap to the fore amid big and consequential events.
sentences.chinese: 在重大事件發生之時，陰謀論總是會跳出來。

sentences.english: This must be some type of right wing tea party conspiracy theory.
sentences.chinese: 這一定是某種類型的右翼茶黨的陰謀論。

sentences.english: But conspiracy theories are kneejerk, lazy cynicism.
sentences.chinese: 但陰謀論是自動生成的，懶惰的犬儒主義。

sentences.english: They both have rejected Fayed's conspiracy theories.
sentences.chinese: 兩國警方都否定了法耶德的陰謀論。

sentences.english: We'll have to put this conspiracy theory back on the shelf.
sentences.chinese: 所以，我們得把陰謀論束之高閣了。

sentences.english: Such conspiracy theories are not rare in Asia.
sentences.chinese: 像這樣的陰謀論在亞洲並不罕見。

sentences.english: Here we enter the realm of conspiracy theories.
sentences.chinese: 在這裏，我們將進入陰謀論的領域。

sentences.english: But this is the rub of course, because conspiracy theories are self-sealing.
sentences.chinese: 但這只是隔靴搔癢而已，因爲陰謀論都是自動生成的。

sentences.english: To the people who called us conspiracy nuts, whatcha think now.
sentences.chinese: 那些把我們稱做陰謀論瘋子的人現在怎麼想？

sentences.english: Some even say it is part of a larger conspiracy theory.
sentences.chinese: 有些人甚至說這是更大陰謀論的一部分。

sentences.english: Other conspiracy theories about Mr Obama are even loopier.
sentences.chinese: 其他版本的奧巴馬陰謀論更讓人摸不着頭腦。

definition: frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
argument/view (sometimes derogatory)
to quote out of context (idiom)
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to use the current topic to put over one's own ideas/to use sth as a pretext to make a fuss
to have an ulterior motive (idiom)
to prattle on self-importantly (idiom)
to shift one's eyes/(fig.) to shift one's attention/to divert attention
to criticize (as a matter of principle)
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
lit. a deluge of heavenly flowers (idiom)/fig. extravagant embellishments/hype
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
to boost support or interest/to campaign/to promote

dramatic form consisting of historical narration/history as jocular narrative/to stretch history for a joking story/amusing story with strained interpretations of history/to make an unreasonable comparison in jest
to defame/to libel/to defile/to smear/to vilify
